Description: Rim and neck sherd of Laconian black-glazed pottery krater; interior and top of rim black; slipped white on external surface of rim,with band of hook maeander pattern between rows of dots; at the left edge of sherd, male head to right painted in outline technique; neck glazed.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Stibbe places this sherd in the experimental section of his Group E, the group of kraters with geometric rim ornaments only (Stibbe, 1989, 33-4).
Bibliographic references: Lane 1933-1934 / Lakonian Vase-Painting (p. 150) ("a grotesque outline head")
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 561, no. E41)
Stibbe 1989 / Laconian Mixing Bowls. A history of the Krater Lakonikos from the 7th to the 5th century BC (p. 34, p. 98, no. E9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GC.42) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
